Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: The role of biodiversity for microbial adaptation to anthropogenic perturbations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Microbes represent the largest reservoir of biodiversity on Earth, drive the biogeochemical cycles that sustain life in most habitats, and cause or control diseases in humans, animals, and plants. Yet, fundamental aspects of this astonishing biodiversity remain poorly understood. For example, thousands of bacterial species inhabit a typical gram of soil or liter of seawater, each encoding a few hundred genes of unknown function. What this diversity means and how useful it is remains poorly understood. This project will employ advanced genomic techniques and mathematical modeling to study the genetic mechanisms that create diversity within aquatic habitats and to identify new, biotechnologically important genes and pathways for cleaning up environmental pollutants such as pesticides and petroleum-based hydrocarbons. The findings are expected to lead to a more predictive understanding of the role of microbial biodiversity for ecosystem function and resilience to natural as well as anthropogenic perturbations, and could have important health and economic benefits.

New multi-disciplinary technologies to study microbes and their communities will be developed and made publicly available. These technologies will have applications across the fields of microbiology, ecology, evolutionary and systems biology, and environmental engineering. Graduate and undergraduate students, including minority students from the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez, will be trained at the interface of microbiology, computational systems biology and engineering, a pivotal, interdisciplinary area of contemporary research that is not adequately covered in traditional academic settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: A single liter of water or gram of soil contains hundreds, if not thousands, of bacterial and archaeal species, each of which typically makes up a very small fraction of the total microbial community (<0.1%), while all together constitute a substantial part of the community, sometimes >50% (the so called ?rare biosphere?). The basis for -and the value of- this astonishing microbial biodiversity remain poorly understood, primarily due to the fact that traditional methods reveal the numerically dominant members of the community related to the flow of the major carbon and nitrogen sources. Yet, it is to be expected that the diversity of (rare) species found in a given habitat contributes substantially to community function and resilience, in particular by serving as a source of metabolic diversity and genomic innovation, and constitutes the evolutionary scaffold that shapes the responses to natural as well as anthropogenic fluctuations in the environment, including major perturbations such as global climate change. Therefore, central to a predictive understanding of the importance of microbial biodiversity for ecosystem function and for the process of adaptation is to obtain a more complete picture of the mechanisms by which low abundance genes and species contribute to community function.

We have developed new bioinformatics approaches for the analysis of rare as well as abundant taxa based on time-series metagenomic datasets and made publicly available a rich collection of multi-omics data from freshwater ecosystems in the Southeastern United States. The freshwater ecosystems include the Chattahoochee River, along with its five interconnected lakes and estuary. The data can be found in the NCBI SRA database under the bioproject PRJNA214105. Our findings show that rare genes and species frequently underlie community adaptation to perturbations such as addition of organic pollutants or crude oil spills, and that horizontal gene transfer during the adaptation period is more frequent than previously thought. We have also developed mathematical models that use time-series data to dynamically represent the ecological interactions among thousands of microbial taxa in a meta-community. These models allow one to assess the healthy state of an ecosystem and make predictions of how microbe-microbe and microbe-environment interactions will change in the future, when environmental parameters such as temperature change. These findings were reported in 32 peer-reviewed articles and 2 textbooks: (Luo 2013, Oh 2013, Luo 2014, Oh 2014, Poretsky 2014, Rodriguez and Konstantinidis 2014, Rodriguez-R and Konstantinidis 2014, Rodriguez.-R and Konstantinidis 2014, Tsementzi 2014, Weigand 2014, Caro-Quintero and Konstantinidis 2015, Konstantinidis and Rossello-Mora 2015, Rodriguez-R. L-M 2015, Weigand 2015, Dam 2016, Ertekin 2016, Meziti 2016, Rodriguez-R. and Konstantinidis 2016, Voit 2016, Faraji and Voit 2017, Faraji and Voit 2017, Huang 2017, Konstantinidis 2017, Orellana 2017, Viver 2017, Voit 2017a, Voit 2017b, Wang 2017, Davis and Voit 2018, Kim 2018, Kim 2018, Meziti 2018, Rodriguez 2018, Viver 2018). At least five more articles are in various stages of preparation for submission at the time of this writing. 

Broader Impacts:Our experiments provided long-needed quantitative information to better understand and model the microbial biodiversity on the planet. New multi-disciplinary technologies to assess the roles of yet-to-be-cultured microorganisms, and new methods to analyze omics datasets were developed and made publicly available. Collectively our results and approaches have applications across the fields of microbiology, ecology, evolutionary and systems biology, and environmental engineering. Innovative laboratory sessions on metagenomics, bioinformatics, and dynamic analysis of omics data drawn from the proposed research were included in courses offered by the PIs. An interactive website (available through http://enve-omics.ce.gatech.edu) was developed to host our analytic pipeline for time-series metagenomic data and allow external users to train themselves with tutorials and analyze metagenomes from their labs. The number of visitors of the webserver has grown from a couple hundred per month in 2013, when the server was first launched, to more than 3,000 visitors/month currently (unique IP address Google Analytics), which is a testament that our tools fulfill a critical need of contemporary research. The project trained 7 postdocs, 13 PhD students, 9 Georgia Tech undergraduates, 3 female minority undergraduates from U. Puerto Rico, and 7 visiting students from overseas (6 female, 1 male). All former students and post-docs have won awards and distinctions for their work such as four best PhD thesis Sigma Xi awards in different years (only 8 to 10 such awards per year are given by the Sigma XI chapter of Georgia Tech among all PhD theses published within the year), and secured positions at Institutions such as Emory University, University of Illinois, and the Max Planck Institute in Germany. All students, graduate and undergraduate, have also received training on the responsibilities/ethics of conducting research and basic laboratory safety from professional instructors.
